reviewText: It is a given that ON THE WATERFRONT is a great film.  It won the Oscar for Best Picture in 1954.  Despite the controversy of his own "ratting" on his questionable friends to HUAC, Elia Kazan is largely considered a great director.  He is applauded as bringing a new realism to motion pictures, with WATERFRONT being one of his most gritty and realistic films.But is ON THE WATERFRONT a great film?  Is it truly a realistic one?  I have watched this film countless times - and despite my great love for it I seem always to come away from it finding still another flaw.  I realize that I love the film almost as much as I am disappointed in it.  Up front, I daresay that without Marlon Brando's towering performance as Terry Malloy, this film would probably hardly be remembered today. (Just as with Kazan's EAST OF EDEN - would this film be held in such high esteem if it were not for James Dean?) It is Brando's strength as an actor that truly holds the film up and makes one almost subconsciously swallow the nonsense that is rampant in the film's storyline and the director's handling of it all. Everything from sound to stunt work, from sequential integrity to makeup is often compromised and sloppily handled at some point throughout the film. Yet somehow, despite Kazan's sloppiness as a director, the film soldiers on and due to its acting, its cinematography, its music score, its on-location ambiance, the film somehow manages to hold high its head and convince the vast majority of its public that it is a great and Oscar-deserving film.Here is a sequential list of some of the disturbing elements I have noticed when watching the film under a microscopic, if you will.  Some of the points below are matters of import that I had never noticed before until this last viewing.  While I have enumerated what I see as the faults of the film, I have also listed other elements that serve to make WATERFRONT  - despite its several weaknesses - ultimately a strong and powerful movie just the same.1) It is a great touch that the film opens with Terry walking up the gangplank, decoy pigeon-in-coat, a punchy pawn to the mob that escort him and well-wish him as he goes to set-up supposed canary Joey Doyle.  Once the ruse has worked to get Joey Doyle up on the roof, watch as Brando releases Danny Boy, the pigeon used as the ruse.  Terry will release a second pigeon into the sky, free of his hands, once Doyle's sister Edie accepts Terry's proposition to go out for a drink.  In both cases the birds have been used by Terry for ulterior motives directed towards each of the  siblings.  One falls to his death, the other falls in love.2) In the first sequence in the back room of Johnny Friendly's bar, Johnny bemoans the fact that "There's nobody tough anymore" and then in comes the one man that will prove tougher to Friendly than any - and that is Terry, whom Friendly first calls "Slugger" and then in a Freudian downgrade of class "Kid."  As he goes to greet Terry, Terry goes to shake Friendly's hand - but Friendly instead engages Terry in a mock punch-out that wonderfully prefigures their battle "on the waterfront" in the film's climax.3) Also in this first scene in the bar's back-room, notice that Johnny Friendly is briefly busied by ostensibly a baby (who we do not see) in a baby stroller. The presumed mother - the only woman in the scene or in any scene in Friendly's bar - has her back to us, kerchief on head.  The presence of the mystery baby and mother would suggest the generational perpetuation of criminality - as it is only after Friendly's visit to the stroller that he reminisces about his own mother and childhood.4) Now some of the sloppiness starts.  In the next day scene at the pier, Terry is the second man with a work token called to work - yet moments later, when a riot ensues and the work tokens are tossed and scattered, for some reason Terry is involved in the ruckus to gather the thrown tokens.  Why?  Of course this is where his relationship with Edie begins with a mock-battle when she rushes into the crowd to try to get a token for her own father. But why is he still outside and struggling for a work token when in the scene right before he was off to work in the hatch? This is just one of many, many continuity flaws that compromised the sought-for realism of Kazan's over-appreciated vision.  Also notice how Edie first gets a cue from off camera as to when to tear loose of Karl Malden's ubiquitous priest.  Watch Ms. Saint's eyes glance off-camera for the cue. "I coulda been a contender!"  Well, "They coulda done a retake!"5) There is a nice prescient touch when Charley the Gent finds his brother Terry in the loft and wants to tell him about his next assignment for Friendly - spying on the imminent church meeting.  Notice how Charley's hanging through the bin slats is a slight forecast of how is body will later be hanging on a fence.  The fact that he is later found hanging by the longshoreman's hook - same as the one Terry's used in his work - is also a significant touch.6) Here is another sloppy moment. It is in the script as filmed, but also should have been caught and better dealt with by the Director.  After the mob's brain-bashing attack on the attendee's of the church meeting, where Edie and her father are separated, Edie moves from terror to the first stirrings of puppy-love with Terry in a most unrealistic manner.  If it were not for the crisp, autumnal cinematography of the on-location shoot - the real church, the real park, the real fires in the trashcans - if not for the mis en scene the scene, as filmed, is completely unrealistic when seen in its entire context.  Edie just lost her brother a day or so before!  Is she to risk losing her father as well just to stroll down memory lane with Terry?7) Note the much-discussed moment where Terry picks up Edie's fallen glove and unconsciously tries it on.  Great moment! It is these Brando-moments that hold the whole thing together and make the film so constantly watchable. Anyway - jumping ahead to the even more famous cab sequence - you'll note how Charley, who has just pulled the gun on his brother and has had its fiery power extinguished with Terry's gentle push of the hand - Charley also has on but one glove. A leather one, yes, in contrast to Edie's knit, feminine one.  This is a subtle comment on the two brothers: Terry's exploration (however unconsciously) of his soft, feminine side and Charley's predictable trappings of gangster-bought expensive coats and manly leather gloves - the leather glove like a shrunken, worn down boxing glove - for, after-all, it was Charley derailed his brother's shot at the title.  The clothes we wear express us.  The clothes we try on indicate what we can be.  Thus the import of Joey Doyle's coat being handed down from one to the other of those who fight the tide on the waterfront, those who want to become something more.  Contenders, instead of bums. (By-the-way, I sometimes wonder if Michael Jackson somewhat got his one-gloved idea from WATERFRONT.)8) Now starts a sequence where things really come unglued and the movie sets all start to cave in on the film's grasp at reality.  There is a startling dichotomy betwixt Terry's gentle seduction of Edie on the apartment house rooftop where he uses the pigeon as a bit of a lure when he invites her to have a drink.  It is a gentle, lovely scene.  Yet Terry's character is completely different in the actual sequence at the bar table where he tells Edie his philosophy of life.  It is a troubling discord. When he calls her a "fruitcake' it is totally out-of-character with the Terry we have just seen tenderly wooing her both in the park and on the rooftop. The fact that there is NO music to be heard during this scene - and then when Edie goes into the main bar there is "Here Comes the Bride" playing and even a whole wedding, in fact, taking place (it is a Twilight Zone moment and I half expected to see Rod Serling at the party smoking a cig) - well, this sloppiness just adds to the reckless feeling of the sequences as they are juxtaposed.  But it doesn't end with the sudden advent of a full-blown wedding not six feet away from the noise-proof table where sat Terry and Edie just moments before. No, the implausible is about to happen en masse!9) So - from the bar where many of the wedding attendees are getting tanked, to the further backroom wedding - in the interim we have Hyde turned back to Jekyll as Terry is now all Mr. Charm again as he dances with Edie. But out of all the people in the world - or in Hoboken at least - who is at the wedding?Many of Johnny Friendly's mob cronies!  And who comes ridiculously waltzing in with the lame excuse of "I was hoping I'd find you here" - none other than crime commissioner Leif Erickson and his "girlfriend" Marty Balsam!  With a subpoena for Terry!  And then when he is alone with his court order and Edie asks him what he is going to do, he defiantly tells her he "Ain't gonna eat cheese for no cops," as if this will delight the woman of his eye.  It totally blows the whistle on his every prior attempt to keep Edie in the dark about his connection to her brother's killing - and is totally out of whack with the film's attempt to make linear and realistic sense.  And in all honesty, Edie - despite her hopefully intense education upriver in Tarrytown - is pretty ditzy in not being able to smell that rat that is dangling right in front of her nose through all of these sequences.  The scene of her running from the wedding looks more like it is a scene of a woman running from Dracula!  In brief, it is totally unrealistic and overly dramatized.10) The sequence wherein the next-to-eat-cheese longshoreman is killed by the accidentally-on-purpose fall of the Irish whiskey crates in the cargo hold is on it surface very dramatic in that it marks the turning point in Terry's change of mind.  But it is also a sloppily shot scene.  Terry is disquietingly in different positions whether it is long shot or closeup.  Would the priest take a ride on the cargo lift after he was just battered by empty cans and dirtied by thrown fruits? Would the slain longshoreman's body be taken from the scene of his death in such a manner? Where are the police (crooked though they might be within this context) or the doctors with the ambulance stretcher?  If Friendly's friends wanted to make this killing look like an accident, why are they throwing cans and refuse at the priest?  It is a riveting scene -  but also a sloppy one.11) Of course, when Terry tells Edie (following the priest's suggestion) that he was the one that set up her brother, she flips out.  It is a dynamic scene - and the use of the ship whistle to drown out Terry's confession and the use of increasingly closer shots of Terry and Edie are artfully done.  But, truth be told, Edie should have known by this point.12) Next we meet Leif Erikson once again - only now he is up on the rooftops allegedly to "rest his dogs" - and Terry seems to accept this silly ruse all too easily and all too easily fall for Leif's patronizing curiosity about his boxing match with Wilson.  This scene isn't too sloppy - but it "coulda been better."13) The backseat of the cab sequence is one of the most famous sequences of film ever shot.  Marlon Brando and Rod Steiger are in a championship thespic match - and though Brando wins, Steiger gets his licks in, despite the impotent gun. But as great as the acting is and as great as the dialog is in this sequence, without Leonard Bernstein's incredibly moving music that perfectly captures a tragic sense of lost possibilities and broken dreams, this scene would never had been as critically praised as it is.  It is a major actor's studio moment, yes, but without the poignant underscore I wonder if it would have risen to the level of greatness to which it did, justifiably so, rise. But despite the acting and the music and the dialog - the scene (within the context of what is happening in the movie's reality) is utterly absurd.  Out of all the places for two brothers to discuss life and death decisions that involve the most murderous of men, why would they pick the backseat of a cab to word-match in?  It makes not a lick of sense.  And, of course, the cabbie does what WE all knew he would do - and that is maniacally drive Charlie to his own doom at 437 River Street. Of course, the obvious stunt double for Brando hopping so suddenly out of the cab once the sequence ends does nothing to help us believe in the realism of said scene.  More on the stunt man later.  But...come to think of it...why did Brando need a stunt man to jump out of a cab?14) Now things go really haywire.  Terry comes a-knockin' on Edie's door, thwarted hormones all a-raging, so instead of knocks he breaks down the door like King Kong crashing through the natives' big door on Skull Island to get to also-blond Anne Darrow. Bernstein's music is as overblown...well, as overblown as was Kong in that other movie, but despite its operatic overkill in parts it is still and all a brilliant and beautiful score.  But...was no one looking?  The other actors, the lighting crew, the script girl, the makeup man himself?  But especially Kazan!  As Charley failed to do, Kazan "shoulda looked out" for Terry a bit more - especially in this sequence.  Terry may have a rocket in his pocket here...but he has also lost his boxer-battered brow. No makeup!  How sloppy can one get in a film of this historic import?  Did no one notice?  And if not - why not?  And if they did, why wasn't the scene re-shot?  Troubling questions to a troublesome scene.  And as a matter-of-fact, Brando's boxer makeup and overall facial appearance vary greatly throughout the course of the film.  Apologists for the movie might say that his physical transmogrifications only mirror his soul changes, but that would be sickening sycophancy.  The point is...somebody messed up!15) Of course, just when Terry gets to plant a great one on Edie the seeds from the rotten past start to grow instead - and Terry follows the siren call about his brother - and it is all very dramatic and the music is great...but how the heck does Terry know where to go so that after the truck almost kills him and Edie the headlamps illumine poor Charley, dead on the fencepost?16) Then Terry goes to Johnny Friendly's Bar, gun in hand.  Not finding his target home, he sits down and asks for a shot. The drinking kind mind you.  So, the uber-professional bartender pours him a drink!  The priest comes in and messes things up for Terry but then has the desire to somewhat challenge his religiosity and orders a beer.  One for Terry, too.  Terry and the priest drink their brew - Terry with bloody arm and gun in hand.  They discuss how to bring the bartender's boss down - and the bartender serves the drinks as if nothing unusual is going on on the other side of the bar!  It is a fantastically inept sequence. But for the magnificent acting that blinds you to much of the nonsense you are watching, the scene always makes me cringe.17) Of course, the courthouse scene is another pitfall.Johnny Friendly doesn't need to have guys pushed off roofs or have precious boxes of booze crush his foes or shoot them and hang them on a fence in an absurd attempt to further warn-off or outright kill rubber-lipped tanker Terry Malloy, no, all he has to do is look at Terry in court and he'll shoot his own mouth off in front of the TV camera, the police, the crime commissioner, you name it!  It is a genuinely stupid confrontation, this court one, and it takes away immensely from the final verbal and physical showdown twixt Terry and Friendly on the titular waterfront.A more astute director would have torn these pages from the script - and never filmed them at all.18) After the pigeons are killed and Terry decides to go down to the waterfront and get back to work for a corrupt system, Edie - who was so gung-ho on Terry's testifying - now turns 360 degrees and starts like George-to-Lenny in "Of Mice and Men" to talk about a farm somewheres, inland...thank god the script doesn't have her talk about the rabbits!  If it did, though, Kazan would have probably filmed it.19) The entire ending is, of course, silly. None of it makes any sense - even when the one longshoreman says whilst watching Terry battle Friendly "That boy fights like he used to!"  The trouble is, none of the watching workers could even see much of the fight as it is taking place behind the longshoreman's local 374 office. The other annoying thing about the fight is the stunt man for Brando.  If anything, the stunt man looks more like Karl Malden if you were to freeze a frame and look close.  Maybe it is Malden!  Why the athletic and macho Brando couldn't have done his own stunts in this sequence is hard to explain.  They aren't that hard to do from the look of it!  Not like what Tom Cruise does nowadays in the Mission Impossible franchise.  Anyway - he gets beat up, Friendly does like the Three Stooges and gets accidentally-on-purpose pushed into the water by Edie's Pop (eye for an eye, this, in that Pop Doyle's son was pushed to his death and now Pop pushes Friendly to his unintended bath) - the priest (not caring about Terry's busted ribs that could kill him at any moment) lies to him about bets being made just so Terry will do like Jesus and walk the walk since talking the talk got him nowhere - and he lets Terry march to Calvary...only in this case it is Resurrection.  His resurrection, allegedly. From bum to somebody.  The shipping boss that Terry stumbles towards looks like Al Capone - but also like Terry's Rod Steiger bro (and Steiger, of course, played Scarface elsewhere) - so Terry goes to be with his resurrected brother and all the men follow, like sheep.  The door comes down.  Johnny Friendly has now completely become a cartoon character as he yells defiantly - and is all alone - that he will be back!  Schwartzenegger has nothing on this guy.  So, Terry goes to work for a pier boss that looks nastier than the relatively friendly-seeming John Friendly.  He shows up for work a bloody, busted wreck and the pier boss doesn't blink an eye!  "Let's go to work!" he shouts - even if it will probably be Terry's last day on the job if not the very planet, internal bleeding and all, and the priest and Edie smile at all they've accomplished and Edie slips her arm into his and the movie ends.  Of course, in Budd Schulberg's novelization of the film Terry testifies and then weeks later a body is found in a barrel in the river, features largely erased with lye, and though no one could be sure it is Terry the workers on the waterfront feel they've seen the last of a pretty rough kid.  Now...grim as that is, that is how the movie should have ended.  An ending like that would have truly been Oscar-worthy - but that is only if the Oscars were and are themselves "Oscar" worthy.  But they aren't and never were - but that is another matter.20) Two last points.  When the priest goes to the battered Terry and he and Edie lift him from the water wherein he was left lying face-down, notice Brando's initial pushing away of the priest.  It is a brilliant moment, probably an instinctive, reflexive response from the consummate Method actor.  It signals that either Terry is so beaten up that he thinks for a moment he is still fighting Friendly and his cohorts, or he realizes it is the priest - and he has justifiable anger towards the priest for all of the seemingly crappy advice he has given Terry throughout the film.  Either way, it is a small moment that almost goes unnoticed - but it is an important moment nonetheless.  The other point - and it eluded me until I recently watched the film with the sound way up - when the longshoremen come back of the building and tell the priest that if Terry walks to work, they'll follow (why they couldn't follow him bravely into work without the necessity of his having had to be beaten up first is a large issue and has much to do with cultural perceptions of manhood) - anyway, they say this...and the priest asks Terry if he heard what they said. "Did you hear that?" he asks again - and then, faintly but still audibly, you will hear two bell rings sound before Terry answers "Yeah."  It is a wonderful touch, a powerful touch to an otherwise ponderous moment.  Two rings - the rings signaling the start and end of each round of a boxing match.  Terry is down for the count - but he hears, not so much the tiresome, homily-addled priest, but those faint bell rings that make him remember Wilson and Charley and that he isn't a bum but coulda been a contender..and so now he stands from the waterfront dock/mat and continues to fight the good fight in order to win.  To win.  To be...somebody.Make no mistake about it, I love this movie. If I didn't love it so, I wouldn't have taken such time to criticize it! But I love it as a movie.  Not as a slice of waterfront reality.  I daresay that Brando and Bernstein have made this film endure.  If Sinatra had had the title shot here and if someone like Leonard Rosenman had scored the film...I doubt if it would have ever become the alleged masterpiece it is popularly perceived as.  Despite it having been awarded Best Picture of 1954, the film is severely flawed.  And it isn't simply that it has aged.  The flaws were all there in 1954 as well. I just think that people then - as well as now - saw Brando first and the movie secondly.  Some people saw it is dated.  It really isn't.  It is just hampered by a schizoid script, clumsy direction, careless attention to details and the vision of a director who was, yes, probably more intent on justifying his personal whistle-blowing than in constructing a fully viable film.Having said all of the above, I still watch and love this movie! It is, despite all things, a classic - with class!

reviewText: On the Waterfront (Elia Kazan, 1954)"I coulda been a contender!" That's the line everyone knows from On the Waterfront. It's funny, because to me, Marlon Brando's truly great scene in this movie comes about five minutes later, amid the fallout of the contender conversation. He's desperately trying to keep from breaking down, barking orders to his girlfriend while getting ready to start a one-man war against the city's crime bosses. It's great stuff. And here I was, having seen the contender excerpt at least a thousand times, thinking it was a movie about a washed-up boxer. Well, it is, but that's only the tip of the iceberg.Terry Malloy (Brando) is a longshoreman, an ex-boxer who's been taken under the wing of union leader Johnny Friendly (Lee J. Cobb). As the movie opens, Terry is seen having a brief conversation with his acquaintance Jimmy, who is soon pushed to his death from the roof of a tenement building. Terry, disturbed by this, goes back to the bar out of which the union operates, protesting that he just thought "they were gonna lean on him a little." This begins Terry's long and painful journey from a longshoreman who follows the "deaf and dumb" code of the union to a man proud enough to stand up for himself and his fellow workers against the corruption at the higher levels of the union.Man, this must have been a tough film to get through McCarthy's goons...Amusing political peccadilloes aside, On the Waterfront really is a great movie. Kazan was at the height of his directorial power, and Brando was never better as an actor. Karl Malden, as a meddling priest willing to stand up for the little guy, does a fantastic job as well, and most of the rest of the cast range from good to great. (There are a few minor characters who seem to be there just for amusement's sake, but they don't get enough face time to really do much damage to the quality of the overall film.) If you haven't seen it, well, it's not just a movie about a washed-up boxer, that I can tell you. ****

reviewText: Most of the various lists of all-time greatest films include this one because it offers a rare combination of superior talent in all areas of production: directed by Elia Kazan...edited by Gene Milford...starring Marlon Brando, Eva Marie Saint, Karl Malden, and Lee J. Cobb...art direction by Richard Day...a screenplay written by Budd Schulberg based on Malcolm Johnson's novel...musical score composed by Leonard Bernstein...with cinematography provided by Boris Kaufman. Producer San Spiegel accepted the Academy Away for best picture. Brando, Day, Kaufman, Kazan, Milford, Schulberg, and Saint also received Academy Awards; Bernstein, Cobb, Malden, and Steiger were nominated. As I viewed it again recently, I was curious to learn how well it has held up since it was released in 1954. It holds up very well indeed.My favorite scenes still have the same impact, most of them involving a conversation: when Malloy teases Edie in the mini-park, when Glover and Gillette engage him on the roof as he tends to his pigeons, the scene in the cab with his brother Charley...also when finds he finds his brother hoisted up on a wall, the scene in the barroom as he awaits Johnny Friendly's arrival, and of course as the film concludes when he somehow gets up and drags himself into the warehouse, followed by the other longshoremen. The integration of dialogue, action, and setting with music in these and other scenes is exquisite. All of the acting is outstanding. In fact, I cannot think of a single weakness throughout the entire production. Yes, that was Pat Hingle playing a bartender, Nehemiah Persoff driving the cab, and Martin Balsam as Gillette. And yes, that was Tony ("Two Ton") Galento playing Truck, one of Friendly's several thugs. There are so many other character actors with familiar faces who never achieved any celebrity but without whom this film could not have achieved its greatness. They include Pat Henning ("Kayo" Dugan), John Hamilton ("Pop" Doyle), and Barry Macollum ("J.P."). They deserve to have their names mentioned.We know now that there was serious and substantial opposition to making On the Waterfront because of the film industry's close ties with organized crime. We also know that the House Un-American Activities Committee was initially much more interested in Communist infiltration of labor unions than it was in any corruption by various mob "families" in the metropolitan New York York area. Nonetheless, the film was finally made. It has lost nothing during the past 50 years and I expect that also to be true for decades to come.

reviewText: It is difficult to come to grips with "On the Waterfront" On the one hand it has enormous strengths, indisputable elements of greatness, and on the other it is surrounded by ambiguities which cannot be wished away...The surface concern of the film is gangsterism in the trade-union movement... The film appears to be concerned with the exploitation of working men by the mob, and thus presents itself as a reformist picture, one that demonstrates a social ill and apparently hopes that it will inspire its cure... However, on inspection, this surface concern seems little more than a gloss, covering up a story whose real concern is the problem of whether or not a man should be an informer...Terry Malloy (Marlon Brando) agonizes over this problem of informing... His moral dilemma is well drawn in the film... The crucial question of whether or not to "squawk"--which provides the film's suspense--is only resolved after incidents of considerable dramatic intensity... Elia Kazan will always be remembered as the director of some of the most vivid film performances of the fifties... His film constitutes an extraordinary tour de force of fluid direction and nervous, edgy acting...The scene between Rod Steiger and Brando in the taxicab--one of the famous scenes of American film--is an example of Kazan at his best... He himself takes little credit for it, insisting that the special way Brando says "Oh, Charley" is the key to its success... But the conviction of both actors, and the total truthfulness of their performances must be credited to a fine director working at the height of his powers...The same could be said for the scene between Brando and Eva Marie Saint, when Brando--haunted by his complicity in the "shape-up" scene, faces a crisis of his own conscience... It is a love scene of enormous power... Brando's love for Edie Doyle, his anguish at what he must say, and her reactions to both, make it one of the truly exquisite moments in cinema acting...Eva Marie Saint is not exceptionally beautiful, but manages to make the blood go through Brando's valves reviving and creating a heart that never existed before... There is a melancholy in her eyes, an exquisite sweet sadness...Cobb is excellent as the arrogant racketeer Johnny Friendly, who intimidates the workers into silence, stopping at nothing to maintain his position of power on the docks... Rod Steiger gives his finest performance as Charley, the clever and suave opportunistic lawyer, who works for the local docker's union headed by Johnny Friendly...Karl Malden is hard and clear as the activist Catholic priest who defies the abuse of labor racketeering, and urges Brando to fight for his rights and control his own destiny, rather than be a pawn in a ruthless system of bribes and killings...'On the Waterfront' is one of the great American films... Not only because it bravely spreads a wonderful light on the violation of justice, but because it is a powerful piece of film drama, which propels a classic study of man's responsibility to his fellow man... The motion picture was nominated for 11 Oscars and won eight... The actors were all convincing, even the smaller parts for thugs...
summary: As a film of concern, "On the Waterfront" is about the best the American cinema has to offer...

reviewText: Is Brando's performance as Terry Malloy in On The Waterfront the best screen performance of all time? Well I have never seen a better one. Watch this film and see why Brando was so highly rated. As the ex boxer turned longshoreman/borderline gangster, Brando gives a perfect performance. Yet Brando does not dominate the film, Karl Malden, Rod Steiger, Lee J Cobb and Eve Marie Saint all give marvelous performances, which but for Brando's would all be remembered as a high point of film acting. Malden, Cobb and Steiger were all nominated for the Oscar as best supporting actor.The story is about corruption on the Brooklyn Docks of the nineteen fifties. It is one of the few American films to portray the working class. The black and white shots of working class Brooklyn are the perfect background for a story of a loser struggling to do the right thing dispite the social pressures on him.Brando and Steiger in the back of the taxi cab is one of the greatest. if not the greatest, movie scene of all time.There is nothing false or overdone in this film. All to often in films and in life working class people are told that the way to success is to move out of their communities and leave them behind.  This film is about real people struggling not to leave their community, but to make that community better. Realism is everything in this film, the acting, the costumes, the sets, the story.  Even today the fight between  Brando and Cobb at the end of the film is shocking in it's realism.On the Waterfront must have a claim to be the best film ever made, it is certainly one of the best two or three American films ever made.Watch and enjoy a perfect film which will leave you gasping at the talent of everyone who had anything to do with it.

reviewText: Ask anyone what pops into their head when you mention ON THE WATERFRONT.  Chances are it's the classic line "I coulda been a contender", delivered by Marlon Brando is one of his finest performances.  Brando plays tough guy Terry Malloy, a boxer-turned-longshoreman working for a group of corrupt union bosses.  He's content working on the docks day in and day out, never putting any thought into his life.  Then he meets Edie Doyle (played by Eva Marie Saint), a young girl trying to find the person(s) responsible for her brother's death.  Soon Terry finds himself falling in love with Edie - and developing a conscience.  In the hardest decision of his life, Terry decides to help the local law enforcement oust the dock's Mob-run union; as with many decisions, this has consequences.ON THE WATERFRONT is fueled largely by Marlon Brando's extraodinary performance as conscience-stricken Terry Malloy, but the film has a lot more going for it than just that.  For one, there's the top-notch performances of Karl Malden as the priest who guides Terry, Eva Marie Saint as the girl who makes Terry realize what's happening around him, and Lee J. Cobb as the despicable head of the union.  Then there's the directing of Elia Kazan, who manages to get the very finest performances from each and every member of the cast.  There's also an outstanding score by Leonard Bernstein and a powerful script by Budd Schulberg.ON THE WATERFRONT is every bit as grand today as it was in 1954.  Brando's performance continues to draw cheers from moviegoers, while some moments continue to draw tears from moviegoers ("It was you, Charley.").  Elia Kazan crafted a masterpiece that still ranks highly amongst the greatest films ever made.

reviewText: On the Waterfront (Columbia Pictures, 1954) was director Elia Kazan's tenth film.Terry Malloy (Marlon Brando) unwittingly participates in the murder of Joey Doyle, a longshoreman who had agreed to testify against his corrupt union. Terry's brother, Charlie (Rod Steiger), is the lawyer of crooked union boss, Johnny Friendly (Lee J. Cobb). Joey's sister, Edie (Eva Marie Saint), comes to the Hoboken docks searching for her brother's killer. The local priest, Father Barry (Karl Malden), agrees to help the longshoreman fight the corrupt union officials. A meeting at the church is broken up by union thugs and Terry escorts Edie to a tavern where romance blooms but Terry is handed a summons to testify before the crime commission. Terry's conscience gets the best of him and he follows Barry's advice to confess his part in Joey's murder to Edie who is overcome with emotion and runs away. Charlie attempts to convince Terry not to testify but is unsuccessful. Terry reconciles with Edie but soon discovers Charlie was murdered by Friendly's goons. He seeks revenge at Friendly's bar, but Barry defuses the situation. Terry testifies against Friendly and the union but to the longshoremen rank-and-file he's a rat and a canary. Terry goes down to the docks for work but when he's passed over by the union foreman, he confronts Friendly directly. A fistfight ensues as the longshoremen watch, and Terry is pummeled by the union leadership gang. Barry helps Terry to his feet and he staggers, battered but triumphant, to work on the dock with the longshoreman behind him.How does one describe a masterpiece? Brando's Oscar-winning portrayal might be the finest performance in film history. Saint is mesmerizing in her Oscar-winning film debut as she holds her own against Brando at the very top of his game and that's saying a mouthful. Malden, Cobb, and Steiger are all wonderful and all were nominated for Oscars. The entire cast is superb. Between the many non-actors, the on-location sets, and the brilliant cinematography (Boris Kaufmann won an Oscar), On the Waterfront has an almost semi-documentary feel. Bud Schulberg's Oscar winning script is as tight as a drum (except for Barry's crucifixion soliloquy). Leonard Bernstein's Oscar-nominated score is exceptional. On the Waterfront won Best Picture and Best Director for Kazan as well as Best Art Direction and Best Editing. Although the "I coulda been a contender" scene is one of the most famous in film history, this movie is filled with many similarly stunning moments. The American Film Institute ranked On the Waterfront #8 on its list of 100 greatest American films. With On the Waterfront, Kazan and Brando changed filmmaking forever. It doen't get any better than this. Amazon reviewers who casually award 5-stars to mediocre and forgetable films should recalibrate.On the Waterfront mirrored circumstances in the lives of Schulberg and Kazan, both former members of the American Communist Party and both friendly witnesses before the House Committee on Un-American Activities in 1952. Kazan denied the film was a defense of his testimony but the parallels are quite prominent.This DVD comes with a lively and interesting commentary provided by Richard Schickel and Jeff Young. There's also the featurette, "Contender - Mastering the Method," and an Elia Kazan interview.

reviewText: This is simply one of those "required reading" films--part of the new Western Cultural Canon. If you are exploring older movies, or are simply exploring, you'll find considerable merit here: an excellent script, a dazzling Brando performance, a cast that's from top to bottom exceptional, beautiful direction, tremendous atmosphere and cinematography, and a dynamic score by Leonard Bernstein. It's almost an exercise in how to make a fine film.For younger people who may not have a good sense of what the past was like, or may have learned too much about certain struggles and not enough about others, this is an educational film. This is what New York City--and most of urban America--really looked like back in the Fifties. Get a good sense of that and you'll understand why so many back then were drawn to glass and steel skyscrapers and big colorful cars with tail fins--between the Stock Market crash in 1929 and the end of WWII in 1945, urban America was a mean and grubby place, and it took till the late Fifties to begin to change that. The mean and grubby characters are pretty accurate too--nothing glamorous about corruption and racketeering back then. It was a pretty sad world.I'm a little bewildered and saddened by some of the reviews this fine film has picked up.

reviewText: This story, about a dockworker named Terry Malloy (Marlon Brando) and his battle against union boss Johnny Friendly (Lee J. Cobb), is I consider one of the best movies ever made. Despite this, some have criticized scenes of the movie and even present debatable underlying themes. Above all else, its said that Elia Kazan used this as an excuse to show why he testified to the House Un-American Activities Committee on communists. But this movie does much more than justify such actions.Now I don't know about politics, so I will sidestep that minefield as much as possible. Though this movie is excellent, I do have however have some quibbles. First, most of the battle lines are too clearly drawn. It's obvious who's good (Father Berry, played by Karl Malden and Edie Doyle, played by a debuting Eva Marie Saint) and who's bad (Friendly and the other union bosses). But there are a few exceptions. For example, Terry's brother Charlie the Gent (Rod Steiger), has been and is working for Friendly when Terry is subpoenaed. This puts Terry in a hole, since he knows that Father Berry is right in having him testify on crimes that have occurred, yet his own family is involved with the managers he will bring down. Thus, Terry is uncertain about who his real friends are until after he testifies. Another problem with the movie is that some of the actor's try too hard. Cobb and Malden overact quite a bit, with many conversations erupting into argument (Cobb and Malden shout about 50% of their lines). But, in my view, they are all superior to today's stars who can't act out of bed. And most of their melodrama occurs in scenes where their characters are or are trying to be the center of attention.Until recently, my biggest grudge would have been with the film's ending, which I originally considered too upbeat, confusing and out of place. But, some recent comments I have received have caused me to reconsider it. Terry's walking back to work following his beating can be paralleled with the story of Christ when he was crucified only to come back to life. The others following him back in is similar to Christ's followers ascending with him into heaven. And, to those who still find it confusing and out of place (Beside myself), the ending is foreshadowed by Malden's speech in the freighter hull after a dockworker is killed. Also, a similar event almost occurred in real life: According to an e-mail I received, a vote was taken among the real life dockworkers as to whether they wanted to replace their corrupt union. They failed, but narrowly. The ending surprised many film critics since it didn't match with the grim mood and most would have preferred to see Terry die at the end or fall down or something. While I too thought the ending would be more downbeat, could these people have done better?Now, to the film's morals. I know that it's hard to sympathize with a snitch, especially to snitch on one who was so good to you. But, this is a film about conscience and, as Terry says, "That stuff can drive you nuts". Let's first understand what the situation is: If Terry didn't rat out Friendly and the other union bosses, he would have more friends but working conditions on the waterfront would have gotten worse and others would get killed. If he does rat Friendly out, it will isolate him from his friends and make life dangerous, but it might help improve working conditions. It was just like when Kazan was forced to testify. If he named names, he would lose respect and if he didn't he would be condemned as a communist himself. Either way, Terry was stuck.But, out of ten points, the above detracts only about  or 1. The good far outweighs the bad.  Scenes were filmed on actual location on docks in New Jersey, giving a gritty, realistic and overall beautiful look that no soundstage could have done. And let's not forget the performances: While Malden and Cobb can be very melodramatic, they are both all right, especially when Malden gives the speech in the freighter. (I'm also tired of people complaining his character's smoking and drinking, since that's not outlawed by the church and some real life priests are doing worse). Steiger gets to share the screen during the "contender" speech. And Saint, for her debut, won Best Supporting Actress (But, she is the main female lead and should have been nominated as such).But, as many stated before, nobody tops Brando. One critic on the website Epinions stated that anybody could have played Malloy. While others were considered for the part (Frank Sinatra was originally cast), I don't think one of cinema's great performances could have been played by anybody. Anyone can say the lines, but can they be said with the same feeling? It's an understatement to say Brando gets involved with his character. If you didn't know who it was onscreen, you would think the actor was also uneducated and dense. Terry is explosive and doesn't think through, a throwback to his boxing days. When confronted with problems, the solution is violence ("Do it to him before he does it to you")."Waterfront" won eight academy awards and was placed at number eight on the American Film Institute's list of the greatest American movies. While it deserves to be on the list, I was surprised it ranked so high considering the controversy that has surrounded it. But, while it may be overly simplistic in it's depiction of good and evil and manipulative, this is still a great movie. The film's documentary style and the brilliant, dynamic work of Brando are still studied today by up and coming actors. Oh and look carefully to spot character actor Martin Balsam as a waterfront detective.
